lemma.description:
Let's begin by looking at configurations and combining machines.

Lemma: If
    $(q_1, w_1\underline{a_1}u_1) \vdash_M^* (q_2, w_2\underline{a_2}u_2)$ for strings $u_i$ and $w_i$ and symbols $a_i$, and
    $(q_2, w_2\underline{a_2}u_2) \vdash^*_M (q_3, w_3\underline{a_3}u_3)$ then
    $(q_1, w_1\underline{a_1}u_1) \vdash^*_M (q_3, w_3\underline{a_3}u_3)$.
lemma.question: What does this configuration $(q_1, w_1\underline{a_1}u_1)$ mean?
answer: The read/write head is on the symbol $a_1$
choices: The machine is in state $q_1$
The read/write head is on the symbol $a_1$

yield.description:
Lemma: If
    $(q_1, w_1\underline{a_1}u_1) \vdash_M^* (q_2, w_2\underline{a_2}u_2)$ for strings $u_i$ and $w_i$ and symbols $a_i$, and
    $(q_2, w_2\underline{a_2}u_2) \vdash^*_M (q_3, w_3\underline{a_3}u_3)$ then
    $(q_1, w_1\underline{a_1}u_1) \vdash^*_M (q_3, w_3\underline{a_3}u_3)$.
yield.question: What do we mean by $\vdash_M^*$?
answer: The machine will do zero or more transitions
choices: The machine will do zero or more transitions
The machine will do one transition

step1.description:
Lemma: If
    $(q_1, w_1\underline{a_1}u_1) \vdash_M^* (q_2, w_2\underline{a_2}u_2)$ for strings $u_i$ and $w_i$ and symbols $a_i$, and
    $(q_2, w_2\underline{a_2}u_2) \vdash^*_M (q_3, w_3\underline{a_3}u_3)$ then
    $(q_1, w_1\underline{a_1}u_1) \vdash^*_M (q_3, w_3\underline{a_3}u_3)$.
step1.question:
What do we mean by
$(q_1, w_1\underline{a_1}u_1) \vdash_M^* (q_2, w_2\underline{a_2}u_2)$?
answer: The machine will change the state from $q_1$ to $q_2$
The tape content will be modified from $w_1a_1u_1$ to $w_2a_2u_2$
The head will be on the symbol $a_2$
choices: The machine will change the state from $q_1$ to $q_2$
The tape content will be modified from $w_1a_1u_1$ to $w_2a_2u_2$
The head will be on the symbol $a_2$
The machine will accept string $w_2$

meaning1.description:
Lemma: If
    $(q_1, w_1\underline{a_1}u_1) \vdash_M^* (q_2, w_2\underline{a_2}u_2)$ for strings $u_i$ and $w_i$ and symbols $a_i$, and
    $(q_2, w_2\underline{a_2}u_2) \vdash^*_M (q_3, w_3\underline{a_3}u_3)$ then
    $(q_1, w_1\underline{a_1}u_1) \vdash^*_M (q_3, w_3\underline{a_3}u_3)$.
meaning1.question: In other words, the machine did some processing on the tape contents and modified it accordingly.

step2.description:
Lemma: If
    $(q_1, w_1\underline{a_1}u_1) \vdash_M^* (q_2, w_2\underline{a_2}u_2)$ for strings $u_i$ and $w_i$ and symbols $a_i$, and
    $(q_2, w_2\underline{a_2}u_2) \vdash^*_M (q_3, w_3\underline{a_3}u_3)$ then
    $(q_1, w_1\underline{a_1}u_1) \vdash^*_M (q_3, w_3\underline{a_3}u_3)$.
step2.question:
What do we mean by
$(q_2, w_2\underline{a_2}u_2) \vdash_M^* (q_3, w_3\underline{a_3}u_3)$?
answer: The machine will change the state from $q_2$ to $q_3$
The tape content will be modified from $w_2a_2u_2$ to $w_3a_3u_3$
The head will be on symbol $a_3$
choices: The machine will change the state from $q_2$ to $q_3$
The tape content will be modified from $w_2a_2u_2$ to $w_3a_3u_3$
The head will be on symbol $a_3$
The machine will accept string $w_3$

meaning2.description:
Lemma: If
    $(q_1, w_1\underline{a_1}u_1) \vdash_M^* (q_2, w_2\underline{a_2}u_2)$ for strings $u_i$ and $w_i$ and symbols $a_i$, and
    $(q_2, w_2\underline{a_2}u_2) \vdash^*_M (q_3, w_3\underline{a_3}u_3)$ then
    $(q_1, w_1\underline{a_1}u_1) \vdash^*_M (q_3, w_3\underline{a_3}u_3)$.
meaning2.question: In other words, the machine did more processing on the tape contents and modified it accordingly.

meaning3.description:
Lemma: If
    $(q_1, w_1\underline{a_1}u_1) \vdash_M^* (q_2, w_2\underline{a_2}u_2)$ for strings $u_i$ and $w_i$ and symbols $a_i$, and
    $(q_2, w_2\underline{a_2}u_2) \vdash^*_M (q_3, w_3\underline{a_3}u_3)$ then
    $(q_1, w_1\underline{a_1}u_1) \vdash^*_M (q_3, w_3\underline{a_3}u_3)$.
meaning3.question: So, in general we can say that the machine started at $q_1$ with tape content $w_1a_1u_1$, did some processing to it, and ended at $q_3$ with tape content changed to $w_3a_3u_3$.

sigma.description:
Here are some of the most basic machines and notation that we will use to build more complex machines.
• $|\Sigma|$ symbol-writing machines (in other words, we need one for each symbol in the input alphabet)): Any given symbol $\sigma$ has a symbol-writing machine named $\sigma$.
sigma.question: If $\Sigma = \{a, b\}$, what does the TM $a$ do?
sigma.answer: write the symbol $a$ to the tape
choices: write the symbol $a$ to the tape
$a$ is just a symbol in the alphabet set $\Sigma$

move.description:
Here are some of the most basic machines and notation that we will use to build more complex machines.
• $|\Sigma|$ symbol-writing machines (in other words, we need one for each symbol in the input alphabet)): Any given symbol $\sigma$ has a symbol-writing machine named $\sigma$.
• Head-moving machines, named $R$, $L$ and $S$, that move the head appropriately.
move.question: What does the TM $R$ do?
move.answer: This TM moves the head to the Right
choices: This TM moves the head to the Right
This TM moves the head to the Left
This TM makes the head Stay on the current cell

not.description:
Here are some of the most basic machines and notation that we will use to build more complex machines.
• $|\Sigma|$ symbol-writing machines (in other words, we need one for each symbol in the input alphabet)): Any given symbol $\sigma$ has a symbol-writing machine named $\sigma$.
• Head-moving machines, named $R$, $L$ and $S$, that move the head appropriately.
• Transitions on anything other than (for example) $\#$ are labeled $\overline{\#}$
not.question: What does a tranistion labled with $\overline{a}$ mean?
not.answer: Change the state if the TM machine reads anything except $a$
choices: Change the state if the TM machine reads anything except $a$
Change the state if the TM machine reads $a$

multi.description:
Here are some of the most basic machines and notation that we will use to build more complex machines.
• $|\Sigma|$ symbol-writing machines (in other words, we need one for each symbol in the input alphabet)): Any given symbol $\sigma$ has a symbol-writing machine named $\sigma$.
• Head-moving machines, named $R$, $L$ and $S$, that move the head appropriately.
• Transitions on anything other than (for example) $\#$ are labeled $\overline{\#}$.
• Multiple copies of a machine get a superscript.
multi.question: $R^3$ means move the read/write head to the right 3 times.

first.question: Which machine will be done first?

a.question: Once $M_1$ ends execution, the head will be on some tape symbol. What will happen once $M_1$ completes if the current tape cell contains $a$?
choices: Start $M_1$
Start $M_2$
Start $M_3$

b.question: Once $M_1$ ends execution, the head will be on some tape symbol. What will happen once $M_1$ completes if the current tape cell contains $b$?
choices: Start $M_1$
Start $M_2$
Start $M_3$

find.question: What does this machine do?
find.answer: Move the head right until an empty cell is found
choices: Move the head right until an empty cell is found
Move the head right until a non-empty cell is found

rpound.description:
Consider this example
We will use the notation $R_\#$ for this process.
rpound.question: What does $R_\#$ machine do?
rpound.answer: Move the head right until an empty cell is found
choices: Move the head right until an empty cell is found
Move the head right until a non-empty cell is found

emptyM.question: What does this machine do?
answer: Move the head left until an empty cell is found
Once the empty cell is reached, the machine $M$ will run
choices: Move the head left until an empty cell is found
Once the empty cell is reached, the machine $M$ will run
Accept the string
Halt

lpound.description:
Consider this example
We will use the notation $L_\#$ for the Machine that will go left until it finds an empty cell. Thus, the two machines below do the same thing, with one using our new notation $L_\#$.
lpound.question: What do these machines do?
answer: Move the head left until an empty cell is found
Once the empty cell is reached, the machine $M$ will run
choices: Move the head left until an empty cell is found
Once the empty cell is reached, the machine $M$ will run
